speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.2: High School Renovation Project - The board will consider approval of funding for major facility improvements at the high school, including building four new science laboratories and repairing the athletic fields. The science lab construction is projected to cost $1,240,400 spread over four years, while athletic field repairs are included in the same package. These upgrades aim to improve STEM instruction and student access to safe extracurricular facilities.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Thanks, Graham.  
I’m really glad we’re doing this—especially since it’s so important to get our labs upgraded.  
Maybe we could check in with Kate about how she thinks the timeline works?  
Is there anything else we need to know before moving forward?

speaker: kateacuff
content:
Thank you, David.

I think we're looking at starting the work next summer, right?

And then, hopefully, being able to move into those labs by fall of '26.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.

That timeline makes sense, but I wonder—do we have enough oversight built in?  

Would anyone mind sharing what kind of progress checks we’ll be doing throughout each phase?

Also, does anyone think we’ve got adequate staffing or training lined up for when those labs open?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Judith.

Kate, maybe we could confirm who'll oversee the construction phases?

Judith, do you think we've considered involving teachers early in planning these labs?

David, could you help us understand why we're spreading the cost over four years instead of doing it sooner?

Graham, do we have any data showing how much safer the repaired fields will be?

Katrina, did we look at whether existing staff can handle the new equipment?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
Thank you all for the comments. 

This is going to be exciting, especially for our kids.

I guess I'm wondering, though, where's the middle ground here?

What do we want to do for the long-term future, versus just getting through the immediate crisis?

Are we going to build something sustainable for our students' futures? Or are we just patching things up until they break again?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Hi, Judith, good morning. I hope you don't mind me jumping in. Maybe we could go back to Kate real quick. I see you nodding. Are we sure we're going to get them done by fall of '26? I'd love to hear more about the project schedule and phasing because I know we're doing multiple projects simultaneously across different schools. So I think it's worth having that conversation.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Katrina.
I agree—we should make sure we’re not stretching ourselves too thin.
Could someone walk us through exactly how these timelines interact with other ongoing projects?
Do we know if delays in one area could impact another?
And maybe we could double-check—does the phased approach mean any part of this won’t be ready until later than expected?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Judith, I appreciate your concern.
It seems like we might need to revisit the phasing plan—could we please get clarity on that?
If we're relying on the summer window, is that realistic given past experience?
Kate, do you think we can actually finish everything by ’26, or is that optimistic?
I’d hate for us to promise something we can’t deliver.

speaker: kateacuff
content:
Well, I think we had an update last week. 
We were told by the architect that they thought we could complete the project by June of '26. 
So my understanding was that that was still the target date. 
But let me check with our superintendent, who has been working closely with Mr. Gougeley.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.
Before we go further, can we please get confirmation from the superintendent on that June deadline?
I’d also appreciate knowing—have we accounted for possible supply chain delays in that timeline?
And maybe we could check—does that schedule allow time for teacher training once the labs are ready?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Judith, could we please verify with the superintendent that June '26 is still solid?  
Kate, do you think we’ve factored in potential material shortages affecting that date?  
Judith, wouldn’t it be helpful to know if teachers get training during the summer?  
Graham, should we confirm that no other projects interfere with this one’s timing?  
David, what happens if we miss that June goal—how do we adjust?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
You know, Judith, I'm thinking ahead.
When do we think we'll be able to bring our seniors back into those labs?
And if we're talking about spring 2026, is that soon enough for them to benefit from this upgrade?
Because I think they're going to be the ones most impacted by it.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Jonno.
I appreciate that point—our seniors deserve timely access.
Can we clarify when seniors would actually use those labs post-completion?
Also, do we have any idea how many seniors will be taking advanced science courses in 2025-2026?
And maybe—would it be possible to fast-track parts of this for upperclassmen, even if others come later?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sorry to interrupt. Jonno, I appreciate you bringing up the seniors. I think it's very important that we keep them in mind. And while I agree with you, Judith, that we should try to train teachers before they begin using them, I think it's reasonable to expect that they'll learn along the way. But I'm curious. Do we have data on how many students will be taking lab-based classes at that time? Because that might affect how quickly we roll out certain features.

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Judith, I’m concerned about the timeline.  
Do we really believe we can finish by June ‘26?  
Kate, can you confirm with the superintendent that there aren’t hidden risks?  
Jonno, how critical is it that seniors get full access right away?  
Judith, do we know how many seniors will take lab sciences next year?  
Let’s make sure we’re not setting expectations we can’t meet.

speaker: kateacuff
content:
I think we have two major issues with the timeline.
One is, does the work start in July, or earlier?
The second is, are we counting on supplies being available?
And then the third is, what kind of disruption will occur in the classroom?
I think we have some challenges around scheduling, but I'm hoping that our superintendent will give us an update.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.
That’s helpful—but can we please get a clear answer on whether construction starts in July?
I worry that waiting that long could push everything else back.
And honestly, I’d like to see a backup plan—if materials are delayed, what’s our fallback?
Maybe we could assign someone to track supply availability weekly?
And David—I’ll say it plainly: if we’re uncertain about the timeline, shouldn’t we pause and reassess?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Judith, can we confirm construction *definitely* starts in July?
Kate, do we know if the lead times for key materials are secure?
Jonno, how urgent is senior access compared to overall completion?
Judith, if delays happen, should we delay opening entirely—or phase in just the essentials?
David, should we pause until we’re confident about the schedule?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
Thank you all for raising good points.
I've got to admit, I don't know how much longer we can wait to move forward.
But I think we're gonna need some help here.
Would someone please contact Ms. Coughlin and get her input on this?
And then, if she says yes, could we please send a note to Dr. Smith asking him to call off his vacation and join us next month?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Jonno, I appreciate you saying that. I'm glad you brought that up because I am wondering if we're making progress on getting approval from the superintendent. I think he'd be pretty instrumental in helping us determine where we stand. So I guess I'm going to echo your request and ask that somebody reach out to him.

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Jud, I agree—we need clarity.
Kate, can you please confirm with the superintendent whether construction truly starts in July?
Jonno, do you think we can afford to wait another month without a firm commitment?
Judith, if we don’t hear back by Friday, should we escalate this?
And Katrin—do you think the superintendent is blocking progress?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I mean, I hope not. I certainly hope he isn't. I think he has been working hard to coordinate these things. I guess my concern is that we haven't gotten word yet, so I feel like we're sort of stuck. Maybe we should set up a meeting between Mr. Page and Mr. Galloway to discuss timelines and see if we can get something more concrete than what we currently have.

speaker: kateacuff
content:
Well, let me respond to David.
We did talk last week about having a meeting with Superintendent Smith and Mr. Page, but I don't recall exactly when it was scheduled.
I suspect that it wasn't rescheduled after the holiday recess.
So I guess I'd suggest that we go ahead and schedule such a meeting now, perhaps next week, unless anyone objects.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.
I appreciate that.
Could we please assign someone to set that meeting—ideally by Thursday?
And David, I’d love to hear what you think about moving forward with a joint session.
Katrina, I wonder if we’ve considered giving Dr. Smith a heads-up that we’re looking for clarity by next week.
If he knows we’re pushing, maybe he’ll prioritize it.
And Jonno—can you confirm if the lab upgrades were included in the original master plan?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Judith, can we confirm if the lab upgrades were actually in the original master plan?
Katrina, should we email Dr. Smith directly to flag the urgency?
Jonno, would you please check the original plans and report back?
David, do you think we can afford to wait another week without answers?
Kate, can you assign someone to set that meeting by Thursday?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.2: Should the board approve funding of $1,240,400 over four years for new science labs, along with athletic field repairs at the high school?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: davidoberg
content: yes

speaker: kateacuff
content: no

speaker: judyle
content:
After reviewing the discussion, I believe prioritizing special education funding is the right choice.
It addresses a long-standing need and supports equity in our schools.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: yes

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Yes.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I voted yes because while I do have concerns about the specific details around timing and who needs to sign off on certain aspects of this project, I also recognize that there is a lot of momentum behind this effort. The students deserve better science labs and improved facilities. It seems like a worthwhile investment in our future generations.

speaker: grahampaige
content: OK, thank you very much for those votes.  And since there were no objections to the motion, I'll declare that the motion passes unanimously.
